questions.question: Write the coordinates of each of the points P, Q, R, S, T and O from the figure.
Plot the following points and write the name of the figure obtained by joining them in order: $P(-3, 2), Q(-7, -3), R(6, -3), S(2, 2)$.
questions.solution:
Plotting the points on the Cartesian plane:

  • $P(-3, 2)$
  • $Q(-7, -3)$
  • $R(6, -3)$
  • $S(2, 2)$

Joining them in order $P \to Q \to R \to S \to P$.

Since $PS$ is parallel to $QR$ (both horizontal lines are not parallel, but checking slopes or visual inspection shows $PS$ and $QR$ are parallel horizontal lines if y-coordinates were same, but here $y_P=2, y_S=2$ and $y_Q=-3, y_R=-3$. So $PS$ is horizontal at $y=2$ and $QR$ is horizontal at $y=-3$. Thus $PS \parallel QR$).

The figure is a Trapezium.

questions.question: Points $A(5, 3), B(-2, 3)$ and $D(5, -4)$ are three vertices of a square $ABCD$. Plot these points on a graph paper and hence find the coordinates of the vertex $C$.
questions.solution:
Plotting $A(5, 3), B(-2, 3), D(5, -4)$.

Since $ABCD$ is a square:

  • $AB$ is a horizontal line of length $5 - (-2) = 7$ units.
  • $AD$ is a vertical line of length $3 - (-4) = 7$ units.
  • Point $C$ must be 7 units below $B$ and 7 units left of $D$.
  • x-coordinate of $C$ = x-coordinate of $B = -2$.
  • y-coordinate of $C$ = y-coordinate of $D = -4$.

Coordinates of C are $(-2, -4)$.

questions.question: Write the coordinates of the vertices of a rectangle whose length and breadth are 5 and 3 units respectively, one vertex at the origin, the longer side lies on the x-axis and one of the vertices lies in the third quadrant.
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Vertex at Origin $O(0, 0)$.
  • Longer side (5 units) on x-axis.
  • Vertex in III Quadrant (where $x<0, y<0$).

Therefore, the rectangle extends to the left (negative x) and downwards (negative y).

Vertices:

  • $O(0, 0)$
  • $A(-5, 0)$ (5 units left on x-axis)
  • $B(-5, -3)$ (3 units down from A)
  • $C(0, -3)$ (3 units down from O)

questions.question: Plot the points $P(1, 0), Q(4, 0)$ and $S(1, 3)$. Find the coordinates of the point $R$ such that $PQRS$ is a square.
questions.solution:
Plotting $P(1, 0), Q(4, 0), S(1, 3)$.

$PQ$ is on x-axis, length $= 4 - 1 = 3$ units.

$PS$ is vertical, length $= 3 - 0 = 3$ units.

Since $PQRS$ is a square, $R$ must be 3 units above $Q$ and 3 units right of $S$.

x-coordinate of $R$ = x-coordinate of $Q = 4$.

y-coordinate of $R$ = y-coordinate of $S = 3$.

Coordinates of R are $(4, 3)$.

questions.question: From the figure, write the coordinates of the points $P, Q, R, S, T$ and $U$.
questions.solution:
Reading from the graph (assuming standard positions):

  • $P$: On positive x-axis.
  • $Q$: In I quadrant.
  • $R$: On positive y-axis.
  • $S$: In II quadrant.
  • $T$: In III quadrant.
  • $U$: In IV quadrant.

(Specific coordinates depend on the provided figure in the book).

questions.question: Plot the points $A(1, -1)$ and $B(4, 5)$. (i) Draw a line segment joining these points. (ii) Write the coordinates of a point on this line segment between A and B.
questions.solution:
(i) Plot $A(1, -1)$ and $B(4, 5)$ and join them.

(ii) Mid-point formula: $(\frac{1+4}{2}, \frac{-1+5}{2}) = (2.5, 2)$.

Point $(2.5, 2)$ lies on the line segment.

questions.question: Plot the points $A(2, 0), B(2, 2), C(0, 2)$ and draw the line segments $OA, AB, BC$ and $CO$. What figure do you obtain?
questions.solution:
Plotting the points:

  • $O(0, 0)$ is the origin.
  • $A(2, 0)$ is on the x-axis.
  • $B(2, 2)$ is in the first quadrant.
  • $C(0, 2)$ is on the y-axis.

Joining $O \to A \to B \to C \to O$ forms a quadrilateral with all sides equal to 2 units and all angles $90^\circ$.

The figure is a Square.

questions.question: Plot the points $A(0, 4), B(-3, 0), C(0, -4), D(3, 0)$. Name the figure obtained by joining the points in order.
questions.solution:
Plotting the points:

  • $A(0, 4)$ on positive y-axis.
  • $B(-3, 0)$ on negative x-axis.
  • $C(0, -4)$ on negative y-axis.
  • $D(3, 0)$ on positive x-axis.

The diagonals $AC$ (length 8) and $BD$ (length 6) bisect each other at right angles at the origin. The sides are equal ($AB = BC = CD = DA = 5$ units).

The figure is a Rhombus.

questions.question: Three vertices of a rectangle are $(3, 2), (-4, 2)$ and $(-4, 5)$. Plot these points and find the coordinates of the fourth vertex.
questions.solution:
Let the vertices be $A(3, 2), B(-4, 2), C(-4, 5)$.

Since it is a rectangle:

  • $AB$ is horizontal (y=2), length = $3 - (-4) = 7$.
  • $BC$ is vertical (x=-4), length = $5 - 2 = 3$.
  • The fourth vertex $D$ must be 3 units above $A$ and 7 units right of $C$.
  • x-coordinate of $D$ = x-coordinate of $A = 3$.
  • y-coordinate of $D$ = y-coordinate of $C = 5$.

Coordinates of the fourth vertex are $(3, 5)$.
